format: A data frame with 1390 observations on the following 9 variables.
reference: Cattaneo, Matias D. and Brigham R. Frandsen and Rocio Titiunik. 2015. "Randomization Inference in the Regression Discontinuity Design: An Application to Party Advantages in the U.S. Senate". Journal of Causal Inference 3(1): 1–24.
title: Randomization Inference in the Regression Discontinuity Design: An Application to Party Advantages in the U.S. Senate
description:
Description
This is the replication data for "Randomization Inference in the Regression
Discontinuity Design: An Application to Party Advantages in the U.S. Senate",
published in 2015 in Journal of Causal Inference. I use these data to
teach about regression discontinuity designs.

parameters.treatment: a numeric vector that is 1 if margin > 0 and is 0 if margin < 0.
parameters.termssenate: a numeric vector for the Democratic candidate's cumulative number of terms previously served in the U.S. Senate.
parameters.population: a numeric vector for the population of the Senate seat's state.
parameters.class: a numeric vector for the class to which each Senate seat belongs.
parameters.termshouse: a numeric vector for the Democratic candidate's cumulative number of terms previously served in the U.S. House.
parameters.year: a numeric vector for the year of the election.
parameters.vote: a numeric vector for the Democratic vote share in the next election (i.e. six years later).
parameters.margin: a numeric vector for the Democratic party's margin of victory in the statewide election. This is the running variable, in RDD parlance.
parameters.state: a numeric vector for the state. This is ultimately a categorical variable.
